title: 113_s2399
content: The "Native Voting Rights Act of 2014" is also known as the Act. It addresses tribal identification and actions for disparities in polling place availability. Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act is amended to allow tribal identification documents issued by Indian tribes to be treated as valid forms of identification for voting purposes. The Attorney General can take actions against States or political subdivisions if disparities in voting opportunities for members of Indian tribes are found, including increasing the availability of polling places. The Voting Rights Act is amended to allow tribal ID as valid for voting. District courts have jurisdiction over actions to address disparities in voting opportunities for non-tribal individuals. Injunctive relief includes increasing polling place availability. Judges must expedite cases related to voting rights violations. An aggrieved person can bring an action to address voting disparities. PROTECTIONS RELATING TO POLLING PLACES ON INDIAN RESERVATIONS. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to include protections for polling places on Indian reservations, requiring approval for activities like eliminating polling places, moving them further away, or making travel difficult for voters. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to protect polling places on Indian reservations, preventing actions like eliminating polling locations, reducing early voting opportunities, or changing voting dates on reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to include protections for polling places on Indian reservations, ensuring that any activities described in subsection (g) of section 4 are not enacted or administered by a State or political subdivision. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow for Federal election oversight on Indian reservations. The Attorney General can authorize Federal observers for elections on reservations if a tribal organization submits a complaint of potential voter rights violations. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for the termination of election observers. SEC. 5 amends the Voting Rights Act of 1965 regarding the termination of election observers. It specifies the conditions for ending observer appointments after the next general election for the office of President. SEC. 6 provides definitions. SEC. 6 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 provides definitions related to Indian tribes and tribal organizations, as well as the definition of a member of an Indian tribe. The Attorney General must release reports of Federal election observers within 6 months. The Attorney General should consult with tribal organizations annually on voting issues for Indian tribe members.
